articleBody.value: Norm Lewis, who made history in May 2014 as The Phantom of the Opera’s first African-American Phantom on Broadway, brings Norm Lewis: The Music of the Night to Kodak Hall at the Eastman Theatre at 8 p.m. Friday, Jan. 27. Tickets to see Lewis — who also received Tony, Drama Desk, Drama League and Outer Critics Circle award nominations for his work in The Gershwins’ Porgy & Bess — are $20 to $65. Go to eastmantheatre.org or call (585) 274-3000.
The Rochester Americans face off against the Albany Devils at 7:05 p.m. Friday, Jan. 27, at Blue Cross Arena at the Community War Memorial. Tickets are $12 to $26. Go to ticketmaster.com.

A Magical Journey Thru Stages presents Footloose, the Musical — based on the immensely popular 1984 movie about a small town where rock and roll and dancing are forbidden — from Friday, Jan. 27, through Sunday, Feb. 5, at the STAGES Theater, on the third floor of the Auditorium Center. Tickets are $13 ($10 in advance). Go to mjtstages.com or call (585) 935-7173.

Winterfest — with activities for children, a bonfire/marshmallow roast, craft vendors, ice skating (depending on the weather) and more — runs from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 28, at the Irondequoit Town Hall campus on Titus Avenue. Admission is free. Go to irondequoit.org/irondequoit-events.

Honoring the band’s late founder, Tony Cavagnaro, The Buddhahood and Friends’ 9th annual January Thaw Tribute Concert is set for 7 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 28, at Anthology in the upper East End. Also on the bill: Extended Family and Bombshell Belly Dance. Proceeds go to the Tony Cavagnaro Young Musicians Scholarship Fund. Tickets are $12 ($10 in advance). Go to anthologylive.com or call (585) 484-1964.

The Rochester RazorSharks take on the Jamestown Jackals at 2 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 29, at Blue Cross Arena at the Community War Memorial. Tickets are $5 to $25; free for children 12 and younger with the purchase of an adult ticket. Go to razorsharks.com or call (585) 232-9190.

Indiana-bred groove outfit Umphrey’s McGee headlines a Sunday, Jan. 29, show at Anthology. Opening are saxophonist Joshua Redman and jam band Spafford. Tickets are $27.50 to $30. Go to anthologylive.com or call (585) 423-1931.

Emancipation Denied: The Story of Black Wall Street is being staged by the North Star Players through Saturday, Jan. 28, at MuCCC. Set in the early 1900s, the play (written by Rochester’s Deborah Solomon) tells of the hopes, struggles and successes of an African-American community in Tulsa, Oklahoma, dubbed “Black Wall Street” by Booker T. Washington because of its economic opportunities. Tickets are $7 to $15. To buy them, and for show times, go to muccc.org/events.

articleBody.value: For the first time, the Memorial Art Gallery and Rochester Contemporary Art Center are collaborating on one exhibition, a collection of mural-sized canvases by internationally acclaimed artist Meleko Mokgosi.

With his figurative paintings that fit together like chapters, suggesting narratives, the 34-year-old contemporary painter explores southern African politics, history, culture, and the complexity of the postcolonial experience in Pax Kaffraria.
This also is the most comprehensive presentation of Pax Kaffraria — six chapters at the MAG and one at RoCo.

“This is a very welcoming work of art,” says MAG Director Jonathan Binstock. “It invites interpretation, analysis and engagement, yet what has kept my interest is how complex it is, how challenging it is at every turn. So you get into it and think, ‘Oh my gosh, how am I going to make sense of this?’ ”
Born in Botswana and based in Brooklyn, Mokgosi’s current work has its roots in four years of study under well-known, American conceptual artist Mary Kelly.

“Mary guided me to find what is normally understood as a project-based practice,” says Mokgosi. That practice, “which is focused not on producing objects but articulating a set of questions, (calls) into question the taken-for-granted idea of an art object as a commodity for private consumption …
“My focus is not on making exhibitions,” he adds, “but on making an argument — the strongest argument I can come up with.”
And arguments that stimulate deep thought or sway opinion take time to create.

It took Mokgosi five years to complete the eight chapters represented in Pax Kaffraria. Only seven of them will be on view, however. Binstock said a space big enough — with climate control and adequate security — was found to accommodate the largest chapter, but “we couldn’t get the crates into the building. And with the weather in Rochester, you can’t plan in the middle of February to unpack a crate outside. It’s just not prudent … I just want everybody to know I tried.”

Mokgosi, who will be at the MAG for an artist’s talk at 7 p.m. on Thursday, Feb. 23, takes a lot of risks during the production of his installations. His work is meticulous and delicate, the layers of paint built up on cotton duck canvas treated with a clear archival ground so that it looks raw; it also attracts fingerprints and dust, leaving no room for mistakes.
“It’s to make my investment measurable to the viewer,” he notes. “It’s also part of the value of entertainment. When you see someone do something difficult, you understand there’s mastery there.”

Sometimes for three weeks, sometimes for three months, Mokgosi, a faculty member at New York University’s Gallatin School of Individualized Study, travels back to Botswana to take photographs and talk to people who will influence future work. These trips, along with reading theory and history, as well as storyboarding, set the stage in his mind for how he wants audiences to react and respond to themes such as nationalism and xenophobia.

“For me, the work is very labor-intensive because I’m dealing with two main elements,” he explains. “One being histories and cultures that really haven’t had the opportunity to historicize themselves the way they should. The other is a much more visible one, trying to deal with how Africans have been misrepresented visually for a long time, and doing that in a specific way that has to do with a very Eurocentric idea of representation, which is painting.”

Mokgosi, who has lived in the U.S. for 12 years, continues: “These are things that matter to me. It’s about where I’m from, where my family lives, where I live. So I try to be as conscientious as possible and take my time.”

The collaborative exhibition presents a formidable opportunity to think about what life is like in another part of the world,says Binstock, who wrote the essay “Meleko Mokgosi’s Pax Kaffraria: Phantom History, Phantom Nation” for the book Meleko Mokgosi: Pax Kaffraria, published by University of California, Los Angeles’s Hammer Museum in 2012.

In addition to hosting one chapter, RoCo also will showcase new drawings the artist made specifically for the Rochester exhibition, according to executive director and curator Bleu Cease, who describes Mokgosi as “a rising star” and Mokgosi’s work as “arresting.”
“His paintings have architectural presence,” Cease says. “Not only are they large — huge, actually — but they also include different spaces, scenes and events within a chapter.”

Mokgosi’s current project, started in 2014, continues delving into the themes raised in Pax Kaffraria. But Democratic Intuition examines in particular how people conceptualize and reciprocate democracy.
As he has with all of his pieces, Mokgosi remains intrigued by how viewers perceive his monumental statements.

“I don’t make these things for myself,” he says. “I make them to engage in dialogue. It’s more about ‘This is what I have to say and what do you guys think about it?’ That’s important for me to know.”
Robin L. Flanigan is a freelance writer in the Rochester area.
If you go
What: Collaborative exhibition of Meleko Mokgosi’s Pax Kaffraria
When: Feb. 3 to March 19 at Rochester Contemporary Art Center, and Feb. 19 to May 7 at Memorial Art Gallery
Where: Rochester Contemporary Art Center, 137 East Ave., and Memorial Art Gallery, 500 University Ave.
Cost: $2 at RoCo; $5-$14 at MAG
Visit: www.rochestercontemporary.org and www.mag.rochester.edu for a full list of events.

articleBody.value: Named after the cocktail concocted by Ian Fleming for his Casino Royale installment of James Bond, The Vesper Kitchen and Bar in downtown Rochester brands itself as a gastropub and raw bar. This is visible when you notice daily oysters and newly rotated beers on tap called out on the chalkboard wall behind a bar that greets you as you arrive. The open kitchen and warm wood furnishings of the interior remains the same from the space’s predecessor, Nikko.

Gastropubs typically showcase superior food options served in a bar atmosphere. It’s a concept that’s still up and coming in our area. ButaPub and Tap and Mallet — both in Rochester’s South Wedge — and Victoire in the East End, are a few examples. But none has combined it with the bivalve-forward raw bar notion. So when they first opened The Vesper in September 2016, I was excited to see co-owners Joe Frocchi and chef Eric Aubriot take on a rare restaurant style.

Along with three friends, I visited The Vesper on a Friday evening when the bar and all of the tables were full. A hockey game at the nearby arena as well as a theater performance both brought in a decent crowd.

Taking on the pub theme, they have six beers on rotation, along with 32 bottled or canned brews with a focus on craft varieties. Wine is also available, but it’s the cocktail program that draws the most attention. Intent on keeping things fresh and exclusive, they stock the bar with everything from their own syrups and citrus juices to cherries they soak in spiced rum.

From the “small stuff” section of the menu, two golden unsmooth spheres were placed on a cornhusk beside a ramekin of garlic chili sauce to make up the corn fritters ($7). Puréed and whole kernels of corn are combined with a hint of cumin and curry before taking a dip in the deep fryer. What comes out is crisp on the outside with a sweet and savory plush interior. Reminiscent of Asian sweet chili sauce, garlic, soy and cilantro are also added to the bold and spicy condiment to round out this snack-sized starter. This dish was the most pleasant for all four of that night.

I don’t know anyone who can say no to a pan-fried sandwich of bread and gooey cheese, so we couldn’t resist the grilled cheese bites with tomato soup ($7). Also a “small stuff” option, a melted combination of the cheese base used in their macaroni and cheese and sliced cheddar is stuffed between ciabatta. This could have been elevated using different bread — something softer and fresher — and with more of a buttery crust. Also on the plate was a personal-size cast iron crock that revealed a coarse tomato soup. A nice balance of sweet tomato and Italian herbs made it the ideal counterpoint for dunking the sandwiches.

From the “seafood bar,” smoked salmon with greens and horseradish dressing ($9) showcased slim cuts of salmon cured and smoked onsite. Frisée, sliced fingerling potato and a mild horseradish cream dressing, gave the option of turning the plate into a sandwich or salad. I opted to assemble an open-face sandwich integrating all of the plate’s components. Overall, the fish lacked the expected smoky flavors and salinity that I anticipated and the ciabatta crostini teetered toward bland and stale.

The Vesper burger ($15) connects with chef Aubriot’s French culinary background. Decadent and perfectly seared foie gras and beautifully caramelized onions enhanced the certified Angus beef patty, cooked to medium per our request. Aromatic garlic mayo was spread onto a pillowy brioche bun. It was another winning dish of the night. On the side, a ramekin of sliced garlic dill housemade pickles and tangy, creamy slaw helped to balance the richness of the burger and its toppings. House-cut seasoned French fries and ketchup also resided on the plate.

The winter chicken strudel ($18) wraps shredded roasted chicken and seasonal vegetables in phyllo placed over a parsnip purée. It was a hearty yet healthful offering during these cold months, but the plating baffled me. An unnecessary mound of mostly undressed arugula covered up the beautifully baked pastry. Greenery on the plate isn’t the issue; its presentation was unexpected.

The seasonal bread pudding ($7) capped off our dinner. This evening’s filling was a duo of fig and almond but I’m told this changes nearly every week. Utilizing brioche as the base with a crowning scoop of homemade vanilla ice cream, it was reasonably sweet, but the texture was too dense, as if overcooked. I would have liked to try beignets, listed on the dessert menu, but they were unavailable that evening.

I had high hopes prior to visiting The Vesper, given chef Aubriot’s James Beard nominations during his time in Chicago plus his extensive experience working within Michelin-starred restaurants. But a plating misstep and lack of inspiring execution with simple ingredients left me wanting more.
Amanda Antinore, a freelance writer, reviews restaurants after a one-time visit.
The Vesper Kitchen and Bar
Location: 1 Capron St., Rochester; (585) 454-1996.
Website: rocthevesper.com.
Hours: Dinner, 4 p.m. to midnight Monday through Saturday; lunch, starting at 11:30 a.m. Thursdays and Fridays.
Appetizers: $6 to $14.
Entrées: $13 to $29.
Diet: Can accommodate special requests and dietary restrictions; Vegan-, vegetarian- and gluten-free-friendly. Vegetarian or vegan tasting platters available.
Handicapped-accessible: Yes. Fully wheelchair friendly.
Reservations: Yes.
Kid-friendly: No.
Attire: Casual.
Credit cards accepted: Yes.
Parking: Free after 6 p.m. and on weekends on Capron Street in front of restaurant; Free in lot directly behind the building off Capron Street.

articleBody.value: Soulful country singer-songwriter Sam Hunt has a 7 p.m. July 23 date at Constellation Brands-Marvin Sands Performing Arts Center.
► MORE: CMAC, Darien Lake announce summer shows

Hunt got his start in Nashville writing songs for Kenny Chesney, Keith Urban, Billy Currington and Reba McEntire. When he broke out on his own, Hunt’s debut album Montevallo went to No. 1 on the Billboard magazine charts on the strength of hits such as “Leave the Night On” and “Take Your Time.”

The supporting acts are Maren Morris, Chris Janson and Ryan Follesse. Tickets ($59 and $49 for the pavilion, $34 advance and $39 the day of the show for the lawn) go on sale at 10 a.m. Feb. 3 at Ticketmaster, (ticketmaster.com, (800) 745-3000 and the Blue Cross Arena box office.
JSPEVAK@gannett.com

articleBody.value: As an alternative, critic Jack Garner recommends:

The Man Who Fell to Earth: This is a mysterious and intriguing British sci-fi film that has become part of the David Bowie mystique. Bowie plays a humanoid alien who comes to earth in search of water for his drought-stricken planet. Pretending to be a human (but with super-human intelligence), he quickly becomes head of a technology-based conglomerate. There's also romance with a sweet, simple and lonely girl (Candy Clark) from whom he learns the ways of earthlings, including religion, booze and sex. Meanwhile, a professor (Rip Torn) becomes his confidant, but begins to suspect his alien nature. All in all, it is a strange but highly original film. It's adapted from a novel by Walter Tevis, who also wrote the extremely different novelo, The Hustler, which was the source material for the great Paul Newman picture.
Director:  Nicolas Roeg.
Cast: Bowie, Clark, Torn.
Jack’s rating: 9.

New on DVD this week: The Man Who Fell to Earth (Blu-ray), Wait Until Dark (Blu-ray), Sherlock: Season 4, USS Indianapolis, The Light Between Oceans, I'm Not Ashamed, Poltergeist III and Boy Did I Get a Wrong Number.
Next week:Disney's Pinocchio (Blu-ray), Bells Are Ringing, The Lair of the White Worm, Parents, Masterminds, Victoria: Season 1, Dr. Feelgood, Tyler Perry's Madea on the Run and Silk: Season 3.

articleBody.value: We start in 1965, and Tony Trischka was a teenage banjo whiz from Syracuse, playing the traditional bluegrass number “Nine Pound Hammer” at a competition in Virginia. “Right in the midst of it I put in some pseudo-Middle Eastern modal stuff,” he says. “One of the judges was Ralph Stanley.
“Needless to say, I didn’t do very well.”

Decades later, the world of traditional banjo has gotten over it. Today, Trischka is at the top of the list, or sometimes right behind Béla Fleck, as the most-respected and innovative banjo strummer in the world.
How much can a banjoist — it’s a real word, you can look it up — do with five strings?

In 1986, the modern composer and fellow banjoist Paul Elwood summoned Trischka to Kansas to play on a piece Elwood had written called “The Void Beneath the Coffee Table.” A five-piece percussion ensemble accompanied by keyboards and harp. Trischka’s assignment: Play the banjo with a bow. And also, play it like a slide guitarist might, except instead of gliding a cylinder along the neck, use a glass ashtray. “Totally atonal, bizarre, crazy, crazy stuff,” Trischka says.

Trischka has not since set ashtray to strings, although he’s confident he could once again summon the skill, if asked. Perhaps if someone brings an ashtray to his solo show Jan. 27 at Bernunzio Uptown Music. Just a suggestion.

Trischka grew up in a house where his parents’ music was Pete Seeger, but also Broadway tunes and jazz, such as Fats Waller. The first time he picked up a banjo, inspired by a Kingston Trio recording, Trischka plucked out the melody to Beethoven’s “Ode to Joy.” That was 1963; he was 14 years old. “I heard it in my head and found the notes,” he says. “Even from the very beginning I wasn’t strictly bluegrass.”

Now, at 68, he sometimes is, sometimes isn’t. There was room for plenty in his formative years. “The Beatles, hipper stuff,” Trischka says.  “Hendrix, Zappa, jazz. The Mahavishnu Orchestra, Chick Corea. It all had time to ferment.”

The result is an intoxicating blend of playing with folk icons such as Peter Rowan and helping to create music for an off-Broadway production of Driving Miss Daisy. Trischka’s backed the gravelly, wheedling narration of the writer William Burroughs and accompanied The Violent Femmes. He’s done the proper radio shows, A Prairie Home Companion and Mountain Stage. And recorded with the Bill Monroe and Ralph Stanley, the two men Trischka calls “the epicenter of bluegrass.”

Trischka passes on this vast experience as a Yoda of the banjo. His many instructional books and videos are the stone tablets handed down from his home in Fair Lawn, New Jersey. Mostly amateurs. He did have one 16-year-old kid come to him for lessons, but, “Within a few months, it was obvious this guy didn’t need lessons anymore.”

Yeah, Béla Fleck. That’s OK. Trischka’s hardly out of work. In 2007, he recruited a handful of notable banjo players — Earl Scruggs, Béla Fleck, Tony Rice — for Double Banjo Bluegrass Spectacular, an album that revived the old double-banjo tradition. It was nominated for a Grammy.

A few years later, one of the musicians on Double Banjo Bluegrass Spectacular asked Trischka to do some pre-production work on his next album. The guy had once been a comedian who played banjo while wearing an arrow through his head. Trischka wasn’t fooled. “I’d seen a video of him playing at some big function, and he was very serious,” Trischka says. “It was this very beautiful song, but people started chuckling and laughing. Because it’s Steve Martin.”

Trischka went on to produce Martin’s second album as well. They lined up some guests for Rare Bird Alert — Paul McCartney, the Dixie Chicks and the Steep Canyon Rangers — and it was nominated for a Grammy.

That’s the crowd that Trischka runs with. And of course, there is a Bob Dylan story. In 1963, the country was just starting to catch wind of Dylan. Trischka’s banjo teacher had a copy of Dylan’s first album, and it was autographed. His teacher knew Bob Dylan!

“He took me to a concert, and we got backstage,” Trischka says. “I remember shaking his hand; he had really long fingernails. He invited us to his hotel across the street. Just me, my teacher and his wife. Dylan asked me, ‘Would you like something to drink?’ And he went down the hall and got me a Coke.
“He was very sweet. This was before he got too famous. But that’s my Dylan story. He got me a Coke.”

And now? Trischka asked one of Dylan’s band members whether he could see Dylan after a show in Binghamton. “He just said, ‘Yeah, ahh, Bob doesn’t do that.’ He stays to himself. Even when you’re connected, you don’t see him.”

Get your own Coke, kid. But Trischka confesses he’s remained a huge fan. “I know almost every song he ever did,” Trischka says. “I have virtually every album.” Out of this came one of his latest musical ventures: Trischka’s Bob Dylan tribute band, Early Roman Kings, named for one of Dylan’s songs. The bassist, Jared Engel, is from Rochester. It is a rare moment away from the banjo, with Trischka playing pedal steel guitar. “I literally had not played it in 35 years,” he says. “I took it out of mothballs.”

Trischka’s newest work is an album he calls the Civil War Project, which he plans to release this year. “It’s something I’ve been working at the last seven, eight years,” he says. “It’s two-thirds of the way done.” And, something he hasn’t done much of, he’s writing lyrics for it. “The world really doesn’t need another banjo instrumental,” he says. Maybe jokingly.

The Civil War Project uses Jimmie Rodgers’ songs as a template, and weaves in stories of a train robbery, a woman who emigrated from Ireland to escape the Irish potato famine of 1848, meeting a riverboat gambler who becomes a soldier in the Civil War.

During the course of writing, Trischka visited a graveyard for slaves outsideAshville, North Carolina, and heard the story of a slave named George Avery. “He was a gravedigger at the plantation. He buried the dead in wicker baskets and put stones without inscriptions over them,” Trischka says. “So it’s just a field of rocks. It was so intense.”

Further studies revealed that while there were no black regiments at the Battle of Gettysburg, there was a black man who picked up a gun to fight for the Union army. Through Trischka’s artistic license, that man becomes Avery.
The music includes banjo, of course, and “an eight-piece brass band in the style of the Civil War,” Trischka says. “And some spoken word from that time.”
This sounds like a banjo concept album. “It’s pretty much a concept album,” Trischka agrees. “But I don’t want it to sound pretentious.”
So with all of this exploration of new banjo worlds, can Trischka still find satisfaction in just picking?

“Totally. I do it every day,” he says. Some of that is due to his online banjo school, where students submit internet videos of their playing and he responds. The students tend to stick to the banjo basics. “It keeps me grounded,” he says.
Indeed, no matter how far a banjo strays, the bluegrass community tends to stay on Appalachian grounds. The music creates profound moments all its own.

As with The Wayfaring Strangers, an all-star bluegrass ensemble featuring Trischka. Lots of guests have joined the band, and for its 2001 album Shifting Sands of Time it called on Ralph Stanley to sing on a track. The perfect opportunity for Trischka to remind the bluegrass legend of how he’d rejected the 18-year-old’s pseudo-Middle Eastern take on “Nine Pound Hammer.”

Trischka let it pass. His bruised teenage ego wasn’t enough to ruin the moment. “We were recording ‘Man of Constant Sorrow,’” Trischka says. “Hearing Ralph’s voice inside my head, with the headphones on, singing that, was one of the most remarkable experiences of my life.”
If you go
What: Tony Trischka.
When: 8 p.m. Jan. 27.
Where:  Bernunzio Uptown Music, 122 East Ave.
Tickets: $18 advance, $20 at the door, $15 for students, available at counter@bernunzio.com, (585) 473-6140 or the store.

articleBody.value: Summertime in Rochester used to bring a colorful procession, fireworks, a little accordion music and all the Chianti you could drink. For years, the Italian Festival was a downtown staple.
This summer, after a three-decade hiatus, it’s back.

Silvano Orsi, who launched a Little Italy Festival in Gates three years ago to promote his dream of creating a vibrant Italian-American neighborhood there, is bringing his movable feast to the big city.

“We want to share it with the east side, with the center of town where it all started — where it belongs,” Orsi said recently. The event, scheduled for the weekend of August 12-13, will be held in a large parking lot near the Civic Center that used to be known as the Riverside Festival Site.

Thousands of people attended the gathering in each of the three years it was held in a Gates town park. Despite some background controversy over the whole idea, Orsi expects even more will come to the new location.

According to the most recent U.S. census estimate for Monroe County, in 2015, 63,320 out of the approximately 400,000 people who identified with a single ancestry group claimed Italian, by far the largest group. Among the 240,000 or so who identify with multiple ancestral groups, German was selected most often, Irish second and Italian third.
“I’m getting a completely different buzz. It’s exciting, and it’s not just Italians excited about it. It’s the community. I think people miss it downtown," said Orsi, who lives in Gates.

Orsi, a lawyer and businessman who does not lack for ideas, also is talking about developing an Italian-American cultural center in downtown Rochester and creating a second Little Italy enclave in the Lyell-Jay section of the city — one of Rochester's original Italian-American neighborhoods.
He has engaged an architectural firm to study the undertaking, which Orsi said "could help turn around Rochester's 'diamond in the rough.' "
That development would complement the Little Italy he still hopes to bring about in Gates.
Rochester city officials are taking a wait-and-see approach on the cultural center and neighborhood redevelopment, but say they heartily welcome the Little Italy Festival.

Their counterparts in Gates say they were happy to host the gathering for three years. But they have lingering questions about festival proceeds, and some officials may not be all that heartbroken to see it go.

"I hold no ill will toward Silvano or the festival. I think the festival was a nice festival. People enjoyed it and had fun," Gates Town Supervisor Mark Assini said. "But there was a financial discrepancy."

That so-called discrepancy came to light in late fall, when Assini examined the financial statements for this year’s festival. Because the event was held in a town park, he said, officials had always checked the financials to ensure Orsi abided by rules that he give any profit to charity.

This year’s breakdown appeared to omit thousands of dollars in attendance revenue that Assini believed the festival should have taken in. It also listed $8,000 in charitable donations of surplus food and cash whose value Assini questioned.
► READ MORE: Little Italy — in Gates?
Orsi was grilled about the matter several times before the Town Board.

Assini paints the examination as routine. “We’re not crucifying. We’re not picking on him," he said. "But we can’t let people use our parks and facilities to profit themselves. We have to protect the integrity of the town and the charities.”

But Orsi believes the inquiry was anything but routine, asserting that other non-profits in favor with Assini never get a similar going-over. He got the business, Orsi said, because he ran as a Democrat for a seat on the all-Republican town board this fall (he lost badly).

Orsi said Assini badly overestimated paid attendance and there was no excess revenue. In fact, he and his family had to cover $13,000 in expenses. “We didn’t profit a nickel, not at all,” he said.

He said he was “stunned” at the attack. “I think Mr. Assini should concentrate on more pressing matters in the town than trying to value the sausages I donated to charity," Orsi said.

The Republican supervisor shrugs off the criticism, saying he never got what he considers a thorough explanation of the financials. “The only response I got is ‘Thank you very much, we’re moving to the city.' ”
'Let them squeak and bark'
Bickering over his desire to create a festival and turn an underused commercial strip into Little Italy are nothing new to Orsi.

He is one of those people to whom other people react strongly. He has been the subject of threats and whisper campaigns, has crossed swords with members of several prominent Italian-American groups in Gates and now, it seems, has antagonized the town supervisor.

He says he is undaunted. “All the pipsqueaks out there that are squeaking and barking, let them squeak and bark. It doesn’t faze me,” Orsi said. “If all this stuff we’re doing for the community is wrong, then I don’t want to be right.”

He promised that this year’s festival, which may be extended to a third day, has new sponsors and will be bigger and better than ever. It will feature food and drink, entertainment, musical acts and more. There has been an admission charge at past festivals.
Orsi also said he would like to have a traditional procession, and perhaps a Roman Catholic Mass, at the opening of the festival.
Italian festivals were a downtown staple for many years. They often began with a procession from St. Mary's Church on Washington Square, and sometimes lasted for more than a week.

The most popular venue was the city festival tent site near Geva Theatre. But city officials abruptly ended use of the tent in 1986, exiling the Italian fest and most of the other ethnic groups that had convened there.

► READ MORE: Complaints kill downtown's festival tent

The site for this year’s festival is along the Genesee River, where the Party in the Park was held in the past. The location, which has been targeted for future development of some sort, is now known at City Hall as Parcel 10.
The festival is only one of several urban undertakings Orsi is considering.

He said he is interested in establishing an Italian-American cultural center in downtown Rochester, and has been talking to building owners. It would have exhibits, food and other Italian products for sale, perhaps offer catering and provide a meeting space.
“That’s how you promote Italian culture. We aren’t doing that now," Orsi said.
He hopes to identify a space for the cultural center in the coming year.
Then there is the development of a Little Italy neighborhood.

Orsi's initial focus is a mile-long strip of Lyell Avenue and Spencerport Road in eastern Gates. A number of Italian-American businesses are located there now, and Orsi has sought to add roadway changes, sidewalks and amenities to make it a more attractive destination. More Italian-American businesses would be lured into the area.
► READ MORE: RIT to help design Little Italy

He announced last fall that architectural professors and students from Rochester Institute of Technology had agreed to help envision the neighborhood. That work was to begin soon. Town officials aren't opposed to the idea, though Assini has made it clear the town doesn't want to pay for it.
Not one Little Italy but two

But now Orsi has his eye on the eastern end of Lyell Avenue, in the city. Once the heart of Rochester's Italian-American community, the neighborhood still is home to a handful of Italian restaurants, bakeries and other businesses. But there are many non-Italian businesses, and empty storefronts as well. More so than the proposed neighborhood in Gates, the urban end of Lyell has its share of impoverished residents, drug abuse and crime.

Redevelopment could include the area around the Rhinos soccer stadium, just south of Lyell on West Broad Street. Perhaps an Italian company could sponsor the professional soccer club, or buy naming rights to the city-owned stadium.

The RIT group may help re-envision the urban end of Lyell, Orsi said, and he has brought in the Pardi architectural firm to assess the neighborhood and prepare schematic designs. Orsi hopes the Community Design Center of Rochester can organize a charrette to gather design thoughts from community members.
Orsi also is working with a neighborhood revitalization company started by his mentor, a businessman credited with creating a booming Little Italy in San Diego.
City Councilwoman Molly Clifford, whose district includes the Lyell area, said recently she's interested in the idea. She's talked to Orsi and plans a sit-down soon.

Orsi has worked with the office of Assembly Majority Leader Joseph Morelle, a Democrat from Irondequoit, on state grant requests and on proposed state legislation to amend existing law that authorizes the creation of business improvement districts.

Such districts, employed in many cities in New York and in other states, allow businesses to gain a level of control over a defined area and raise money for infrastructure, beautification and security. (One was discussed for downtown Rochester three years ago but never created.)

Orsi has always planned on creating a district to oversee development of his Little Italy. He has proposed to modify state law to authorize a variant called community benefit districts, which would function similarly but allow residents and other institutions to join businesses in funding and managing the district.
Orsi believes moving his festival to Rochester, and carving out a second Little Italy neighborhood in the city, won't hurt his plans to revitalize the Gates strip.

"We want to shoot for the stars ... and revitalize that whole bi-municipal Lyell Avenue corridor, including the Gates Little Italy area that we've initially targeted for revitalization," he said. "Both areas are truly ripe for revitalization, and they have needed attention for years.  Now perhaps a real opportunity to get it done has arisen."
SORR@Gannett.com
Includes reporting by staff writer Sean Lahman.

articleBody.value: A trio of new on-sale dates, all featuring multiple artists, has been confirmed for three different area venues this summer.

Journey is joined by Asia for a 7:30 p.m., June 21 show at Blue Cross Arena. The concert by the ’70s classic-rock giants goes on sale at 10 a.m. Jan. 27. Tickets ($85, $65, $45 and $35) will be at Ticketmaster, livenation.com, (800) 745-3000, ticketmaster.com and the Blue Cross Arena box office.

Rod Stewart and Cyndi Lauper play 7:30 p.m. July 29 at Constellation Brands-Marvin Sands Performing Arts Center. Tickets ($175 and $85 for the pavilion, $39.50 advance, $45 the day of the show for the lawn) go on sale at 10 a.m. Jan. 27 at Ticketmaster, (ticketmaster.com, (800) 745-3000 and the  Blue Cross Arena box office.

Darien Lake’s Country Megaticket package will include five concerts: Jason Aldine, Florida Georgia Line, Dierks Bentley, Lady Antebellum and Luke Bryan. They go on sale at 10 a.m. Jan. 27. The lineup:
Jason Aldean, Chris Young and Kane Brown, June 3.
Florida Georgia Line and Nelly and Chris Lane, June 16.
Dierks Bentley with Cole Swindell and Jon Pardi, Aug. 4.
Lady Antebellum with Kelsea Ballerini and Brett Young. Aug. 10.
Luke Bryan with Brett Eldredge and more names to be announced, Aug. 25.

One ticket to each of the five Megaticket shows is $600 and $500 for the pavilion, $150 for the lawn. The $600 level also includes one parking pass per pair of Megatickets. Lawn tickets can be upgraded to “preferred lawn area” tickets for an additional $60 for all five shows. They're available at megaticket.com.

The Megaticket concerts join previously announced Darin Lake shows with The Zac Brown Band June 25; Third Eye Blind and Silversun Pickups June 29; Foreigner, Cheap Trick and the Jason Bonham Led Zeppelin Experience July 21; Green Day Aug. 25; and Chicago and The Doobie Brothers July 18.

Stewart and Lauper join four shows thus far at CMAC: Dave Matthews and his longtime songwriting partner and guitarist, Tim Reynolds on June 4; Idina Menzel July 15; Santana Aug. 18; and a sold-out Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers on July 2.
JSPEVAK@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: The Eastman Presents concert series is delivering another Broadway superstar.

Norm Lewis, who in 2014 became the first African-American man to play The Phantom in The Phantom of the Opera, is coming to Kodak Hall at Eastman Theatre for a performance specially crafted for Rochester.

The Tony Award-nominated performer and actor (whose work has included recurring TV roles) is a veteran of some two dozen shows and plays. For his performance here, unlike with many such shows, Lewis will have more than a standard rhythm section backing him. Instead, a 40-piece orchestra — including Eastman students — will accompany him.

The concert will feature selections from the Great American Songbook, Broadway and some pieces from Lewis’ most celebrated performances. It’s titled “The Music of the Night,” after the famous song in Phantom.
Ironically, Lewis never had an inkling or drive to break these barriers or to become a star in the Broadway world.

The native of Tallahassee, Florida, had his first job in journalism at the Orlando Sentinel, beginning in production and eventually working his way up to marketing over the course of about five years. So where did the theater training begin?

“My junior year in high school, I needed an elective. I sang in church, but I never knew I had ‘a voice,’” Lewis said. He ended up picking choir simply because he had sung in church already. At that time, he was an accomplished tennis player and was considering playing professionally. But it was in the arts where he truly started making an impression.
“The choral director saw something in me … He started giving me solos, and I started receiving accolades from those solos,” he explained.

It sparked more of an interest in Lewis, but he still thought of performing as merely a hobby. He went to college, majoring in business, but kept up singing with a choir, along with doing the occasional play, in addition to working on his own projects.
“I actually got discovered at a bar, singing,” Lewis said matter-of-factly.

From there, Lewis, now 53, would go on to bigger and bigger roles as an actor, singer and performer. Starting in the 1990s, Lewis appeared on Broadway as John in Miss Saigon, played the lead role in Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street and originated the role of King Triton in The Little Mermaid. Those two roles helped move him into the limelight.

From 2006 to 2007, he played Javert in Les Miserables, and from 2011 to 2012 he played the title role in Porgy and Bess. His portrayal of Porgy garnered him a Tony nomination for Best Actor in a Musical.
Lewis credits a quirk of his musical upbringing that gave him the flexibility to take on and prepare for Broadway roles.

“When I was in church, I was never given solos, so I didn’t acquire the typical ‘gospel voice,’” Lewis said. “The singers that I looked up to were the crooners: Dean Martin, Sammy Davis Jr., and my favorite Johnny Mathis.”
This style of singing, Lewis says, allowed him to develop a sound that wouldn’t pigeonhole him into only typically African-American parts. To this day, he still thinks of himself as a crooner.
Lewis speaks modestly and humbly about the barriers he has broken.

“Barriers, they still exist,” said Alicia Rosser, a senior vocal performance major at Eastman. Rosser has held the William Warfield Scholarship — an Eastman scholarship dedicated to promising African-American vocal students — for three years. “However, I think the platform for the creative work of an artist needs to be a diverse and accepting one. I am proud when these barriers are broken.”

In addition to his sound, Lewis’ acting ability has set him apart. Director of Concert Activities Keith Elder said that Lewis immerses himself so deeply in a role that in each performance, “you can’t tell it’s (Lewis) performing.”

Lewis said, with each role, he tries to find the truth of each character and bring it out, through extensive research and preparation. He has even carved out a TV acting career as well; fans of the show Scandal will recognize Lewis as Sen. Edison Davis.
“I find him extremely versatile and charismatic as an artist,” said Rosser. “His artistic output is diverse and exciting to watch. His singing voice is rich, and his stage deportment is earnest.”

Norm Lewis’s performance is also the first in a new ticket package for the Eastman Presents series. Elder, who is serving his final year as director of concert activities, wanted to create a better and more convenient way to “bring the arts to Rochester” from now until March, and help us through “the winter blues.”

The package brings a 15 percent discount for people buying tickets for the final four performances of the series — Norm Lewis, Garrison Keillor, the St. Petersburg Philharmonic Orchestra with pianist Nikolai Lugansky, and dancer Savion Glover. The processing fee is waived, as well.
If you go
What: Barrier-breaking Broadway performer and actor Norm Lewis performs “The Music of the Night,” featuring an all-Rochester orchestra.
Where/When: 8 p.m. Jan. 27, Kodak Hall at Eastman Theatre, 60 Gibbs St., Rochester

Tickets: Tickets start at $26, and may be purchased online at eastmantheatre.org/events, or by calling the Eastman Theatre box office at (585) 274-3000. To purchase the package for the final four Eastman Presents events, go to eastmantheatre.org and click on "Buy," then "Subscriptions."

articleBody.value: Leslie Zinck Ward really loves Rochester.

Saturday, in the courtyard of her Henrietta restaurant, the Lovin' Cup, 300 Park Point Drive, she (and a whole mess of others) will show just how much she loves this city. Craft beer nerds and foodies will gather in a giant outdoor tent for the sixth edition of Homegrown. Co-hosted by Rochester's Three Heads Brewing, Homegrown highlights the best in Rochester-area craft beer, cider, spirits and food.

“We’re really celebrating what makes this city special,” Zinck Ward said. “And because we’re doing it outdoors in the middle of January, it’s very western New York. There’s just such a genuine, organic vibe. It just comes from embracing what all of these people are doing. Everyone embraces each other and celebrates each other.”
READ MORE:
► First craft brewery opens in Livingston County
► Ranking Rochester's recent IPAs
► Selecting New York's 10 best breweries
► Best beers during a memorable 2016

Tickets are $30. They can be purchased at Lovin' Cup and Three Heads. Tickets are also available online. There will be some great local live music from the likes of Danielle Ponder and the Tomorrow People, Honey Smugglers, the Moho Collective and others. There are also some wonderful restaurants like the Cub Room, Hose 22, The Vesper, Marshall Street, Pizzeria FAVO, and others.

People can experience samples of craft beverages and food from many establishments in this region. Over 40 breweries pouring in three-hour shifts until 9 p.m. (I'm most excited for return of Stoneyard's magical Toasted Coconut Kareem Ale.) Music runs from noon to 1 a.m. Over 2,000 people attended last year.
WCLEVELAND@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: ALBANY - Gov. Andrew Cuomo's proposal to allow movie theaters to serve alcohol wouldn't limit them to just beer and wine, despite the governor saying otherwise.

Tucked into Cuomo's $152.3 billion state budget proposal was a measure that would clear the way for movie theaters to receive an alcohol license, regardless of whether they have a kitchen or table seating.
Cuomo told reporters late Tuesday that theaters would be limited to beer and wine sales, not liquor.
His actual proposal, however, includes no such limitation. Nor does it include state-backed incentives for the theaters to serve New York-made beers and wines, which Cuomo also said was included.
READ MORE
► Beer and a movie? NY could make it happen
► Cuomo to balance budget with millionaire's tax
► You vape, bro? Cuomo wants vape tax
A spokesman said the measure is still aimed at promoting beer and wine.
"The intent is to provide licenses to serve alcohol in theatres, with the focus on beer and wine," Cuomo budget spokesman Morris Peters said in an email Thursday.
Current state law prohibits movie theaters from serving alcohol, unless they serve restaurant-style food and have table seating available for all patrons.

Cuomo's proposal — included in one of the 10 bills needed to approve the state budget — would remove the food and seating restrictions, allowing movie theaters to apply for an alcohol license if they serve traditional concessions like popcorn and candy.
It would need lawmaker approval to take effect. The state faces a March 31 deadline for an on-time budget.
During a briefing Tuesday night with reporters, Cuomo was asked specifically whether his plan would allow theaters to serve spirits.
"Oh, no, no," Cuomo said with a chuckle. "Just wine and beer. Let's not go too far."
While the proposal doesn't restrict the type of alcohol movie theaters can serve, the State Liquor Authority could limit it later through regulations.
Earlier in the briefing, Cuomo also said his plan would be "joined with an incentive program, to incentivize the movie theaters to sell New York wine and beer."
His budget proposal does not appear to include such a plan, and his office didn't explain what he was suggesting.
Cuomo's plan would only allow movie theaters to serve patrons of PG-13, R and NC-17 movies, and they would only be able to buy one drink at a time.
Major movie theater chains have not yet weighed in on Cuomo's proposal.

But the state chapter of the National Organization of Theatre owners, backed by funding from AMC Theatres and Regal Cinemas, has lobbied for alcohol in recent years, according to state disclosure documents.
Robert Sunshine, executive director of the state chapter, didn't respond to messages seeking comment.

content.author: Jon Campbell, @JonCampbellGAN
content.headline: Liquor, too? Cuomo's movie plan not limited to beer, wine

articleBody.value: Hey Webster! Our hometown girl (and fiddling phenom) Kate Lee will be back in town tomorrow night, performing with Forrest O'Connor and Wisewater at Nazareth College's Callahan Theater.
Here's a bit more about the group, from the website:

Nashville-based Americana duo WISEWATER has earned praise from the likes of Alison Krauss, Rosanne Cash, Mary Gauthier, and others for their lyrical honesty and clarity, infectious melodies, tight harmonies, instrumental virtuosity, and deep sense of groove. Members Kate Lee and Forrest O’Connor are two young, positive, worldly artists whose songs blend roots, country, rock, and progressive acoustic music in a refreshing and accessible way.
The concert is Friday night January 20, and will begin at 8 pm. Tickets are start at $25 and can be purchased by clicking here.

articleBody.value: Oscar-winning film composer Elliot Goldenthal devised his new work, Waltz and Agitato, “Pravda,” to be the ideal overture to two orchestral masterworks.

Because you don’t just jump from a pleasant, mild-winter Rochester afternoon into the Russian landscape of Shostakovich’s Fifth Symphony, even if it’s followed by soprano Nicole Cabell singing in Ravel’s Shéhérazade.
And so, it’s Pravda to the rescue. It’ll have its world premiere in the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra’s next Philharmonics Series concert, on Thursday, Jan. 26, and again Saturday, Jan. 28.

Goldenthal, who won an Academy Award in 2002 for his score to the motion picture Frida, was a protegé of Aaron Copland and also studied with John Corigliano. If you’ve seen such films as Interview with the Vampire, Alien 3, Michael Collins, Batman Forever, and Heat, you’ve heard his music.
READ MORE:
► Stare, Tyzik to unveil 2017-'18 RPO concert season Feb. 7
► Violinist James Ehnes to play perfect piece with RPO
► Violin virtuoso James Ehnes dazzles, delights with RPO
► Amy Grant, RPO, and what she learned before she dies

Dmitri Shostakovich himself, coincidentally, also wrote music for film. When the official Soviet newspaper Pravda assailed his work in early 1936, he was working on his fourth symphony, and the Stalin-driven critique left him beyond shaken. In the aftermath, he went on to write his fifth symphony in three months in 1937.

“I’m not being political, personally, about that time,” Goldenthal said, “other than the fact that composers and artists and writers and playwrights lived under a tremendously tight screw under that regime — journalists as well.”

“So Pravda struck me as a funny thing because it was a state-run newspaper meaning ‘truth,’ and quite often it was a manipulation of the truth for their own means and ends. Kind of like Breitbart or something.”

Goldenthal’s work manages to create a bridge between the early 20th century and now. In a way, he said, the piece he has written is a tribute to composers of that earlier era and a warning and reminder of what can happen when the press isn’t free.

“It’s really reflective of the difficult times, the tenuous times that Soviet composers like Prokofiev, Kabalevsky, Shostakovich, to name a few, had in trying to write with always having censorship issues, and having a newspaper called The Truth, or Pravda, that was constantly manipulating their lives in the sense that many reviews about their work were just self-serving in terms of the propaganda of the government at the time.”
Two opposing elements clash in Waltz and Agitato, “Pravda,” as romance and a carefree existence tangle with agitation.
“So it’s the idea of dancing with a kind of abandon and at the same time realizing that just outside your window, where you’re dancing around, there’s a tremendous turbulence,” Goldenthal said.
Throughout Shostakovich’s compositions, Goldenthal added, listeners can pick up on his personal code.

“His composition was, in a sense, a series of enigmas that couldn’t really be figured out by the art police. His symphonies have glimpses into the psychological, personal world that former composers like Mahler had achieved. He had a fierce personal style, where his tapestry, his canvas, was a giant symphony orchestra.”
For Goldenthal, writing for film is one thing, and writing for, well, others is something else entirely.

“A lot of film works are huge orchestral pieces, and others are solo guitar or solo piano, so there’s no formula in writing for film. Many of my film works are for full orchestra. They’re the same forces. But the difference between writing a personal piece that’s not attached to another work is just that word: personal.”

The performance of Goldenthal’s work continues the thread of music by American composers throughout this season for the RPO. And Music Director Ward Stare is confident the work will be a perfect introduction to the evening.

“It deals with the conflict of the machinery and the brutal dictator in Stalin and sort of the soulless atmosphere,” Stare said, “and contrasts that with kind of a troubadour, romantic, more hopeful element.”

Stare and Goldenthal first collaborated about two years ago, when the string ensemble that Stare conducts at the McDuffie Center for Strings at Mercer University in Macon, Georgia, premiered Goldenthal’s “Lyric Suite for Strings.”
Over the course of rehearsing, the two talked about other music Goldenthal had written that hadn’t found a proper place to be performed.
“He’s an Academy Award-winning film composer, so that tends to get one pigeonholed, in some ways,” Stare said.
Waltz and Agitato, “Pravda” originated a few years ago, as Goldenthal was working on a movie project.

“It came up as shards,” he said. “I wanted to have a futuristic, totalitarian feel to a waltz I was writing. And then some years after that, I realized I should revisit this because It had good kernels of ideas in it.”
Goldenthal said he ultimately designed the piece to function as an introduction to Stare’s program, but Stare insisted that the work wasn’t written expressly for Rochester.
“This was something that he already had composed,” Stare said. “But he made a few adjustments to it. He did revise it a little bit for us. But it just happened that it worked out really well.
“I’m thrilled to be able to feature his music in Rochester because many of us have heard it on the big screen, but it really deserves to be heard in the concert hall as well.”
Jann Nyffeler, a Rochester-based freelance journalist, is a recovering violinist who began her classical music career at WCPE-FM in North Carolina.
If you go

What: The Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, performing the world concert premiere of Waltz and Agitato, “Pravda,” by Elliot Goldenthal; Shéhérazade by Maurice Ravel, featuring soprano Nicole Cabell; and Symphony No. 5 by Dmitri Shostakovich. Music Director Ward Stare conducts.
When: 7:30 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 26; 8 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 28
Where: Kodak Hall at Eastman Theatre, Rochester
Tickets: $23-103. Go to www.rpo.org, or call (585) 454-2100, at most Wegmans locations and at the RPO Patron Services Center, 108 East Ave.
Being social: Being social: Follow the RPO on Twitter @RochesterPhil. On Instagram, look for rochesterphilharmonic.

content.shortHeadline: Composer's world premiere with RPO
content.about: Oscar-winning film composer Elliot Goldenthal devised his new work, Waltz and Agitato, “Pravda,” to be the ideal overture to two orchestral masterworks.Because you don’t just jump from a pleasant, mild-winter Rochester afternoon into the Russian landscape of Shostakovich’s Fifth Symphony, even if it’s followed by soprano Nicole Cabell singing in Ravel’s Shéhérazade.And so, it’s Pravda to the rescue. It’ll have its world premiere in the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra’s next Philharmonics Series concert, on Thursday, Jan. 26, and again Saturday, Jan. 28.Goldenthal, who won an Academy Award in 2002 for his score to the motion picture Frida, was a protegé of Aaron Copland and also studied with John Corigliano. If you’ve seen such films as Interview with the Vampire, Alien 3, Michael Collins, Batman Forever, and Heat, you’ve heard his music.

articleBody.value: When it comes to food and beverage hot spots, Rochester's South Wedge neighborhood is buzzing with more than 20 establishments that can satisfy just about any craving — morning, noon and night.

From artisan chocolates, to a brewery, butchery and gourmand open-face sandwiches, each location reveals a unique flavor — in personality and taste. Chris Jones, co-chair of the Business Association of the South Wedge Area, credits Cheesy Eddie’s (which opened in 1976) and Premier Pastry (which has been open at its current location since 1991) as original destinations that set the foundation for other culinary offerings to follow.

“Over the past 10 years we really started seeing growth begin,” says Jones, who adds that the additional surge of openings throughout the last couple of years is bringing a lot of new people into the neighborhood. “There’s a strong sense of community. Most business owners (herself included) live and work in the neighborhood, so we are doubly invested.”

Choosing the destination for a food crawl was easy; narrowing down our visits to just three locations was the challenge. On a Tuesday night, my food-loving friends Melody, Philip and Lora braved the winter elements left over from morning flurries and afternoon freezing rain to join me on diverse food frenzy with zigzag stops along South Avenue, Gregory Street and South Clinton Avenue.
'Hot wine' and snack flights

Situated at a corner of South Avenue and Hickory Street is Solera Wine Bar (647 South Ave.). The chill from the cold night instantly melted away as we soaked in the rustic and intimate ambience of wooden tables that flickered with candles, a long wooden bar, exposed brick walls and an ornate chandelier dangling from the ceiling. The first to arrive, we gravitated toward a front nook surrounded by oversized windows made cozy with red velvet drapery.

Owner John Fanning explains that Solera leans toward smaller-production, family-owned wineries that make real wine with soul. “My taste tends to lean towards Old World wines, which I also find to be some of the great values of the wine world, so our list is generally rather European-heavy,” he says. “In the end, the idea is to represent as many different styles of wine from as many different places in the world as possible.”

Interested in Italian reds, bartender Sam Bovard recommended the Arianna Occhipinti SP68, a red blend of Frappato and Nero d'Avola. He described the bottle as fruity and effervescent, adding that the Occhipinti  name is hot in wine right now and well known in Sicily (SP68 is the road the winery is located on). Fanning later added that there is a wine movement around the world to basically return to roots, no bothering with trendy terms such as "natural wine" — just making wine in as pure and honest a way as possible.

“Arianna is in her early 30s, drives the tractor, takes care of the vineyards, and processes the grapes with as minimal intervention as possible to truly express the vineyards,” he says. “I feel lucky to get a case of her wines every year.”

Tastings of the Occhipinti were offered before we all happily committed, and because the Vin Chaud (hot mulled wine offered during the winter months) sounded comforting, I added a $6 glass to our order. Bovard poured each of our glasses ($12) with the smooth red, and returned shortly after with the fragrant Vin Chaud, a California red blend that was sweetened with lovely seasonal winter spices.

Our two appetizers, neatly arranged and presented on wooden boards, exposed us to flavors from around the world. Bovard first explained the olive oil flight from top to bottom — Spanish (the lightest in flavor and texture), followed by Italian (a bit denser) and finally Greek (the boldest). We ripped apart the accompanying baguette to saturate the pieces into each of the oils. The Greek ramekin was revealed as the group favorite when we realized it was the first to be emptied.

The flight naturally led into discussions of our own travels around the world, including Philip’s trip to Thailand and Lora’s visit to Spain, and discoveries of local specialty grocery stores that have allowed them to try their hands at re-creating international dishes.

The flavorful cheese board selection included a Spanish goat cheese with a rind that had been soaked in red wine, a Spanish manchengo and a Welsh cheddar with mustard seeds and brown ale. A side of apple slices and dried apricots lightly drizzled in honey brought in sweet notes. We were all taken with the assertive cheddar, which for Melody sparked a childhood memory of her favorite type of sandwich, cheese and mustard. While it didn’t resonate with me, I found it entertaining that the other two immediately jumped aboard her memory train in agreement.
Asian-inspired fare and beyond

Over at ButaPub (315 Gregory St., No. 2), the décor was as eclectic as the Tuesday night activities. Red S-shaped seating was arranged around dining tables, local artwork (some surrealistic) adorned the walls, and while one corner of the dining room reflected a lounge area with couches and a fireplace, the opposite end featured an active pool table. In addition to diners who were seeking out the Asian-inspired fare, community members were playing in a pool league, and a couple of artists had set up easels to take advantage of “Late Night Paint” (artists gather to create and share supplies and ideas the second Tuesday of each month).

As we studied the dinner offerings, categorized into small stuff, bowls, baos (steamed buns), plates and sides, playful menu components caught our eye. The menu’s flip side features a comic drawn by one of the servers depicting the best way to eat ramen, and the cocktails, with offerings such as “You’ll Shoot Your Eye Out” and “Never Feed Him After Midnight," were all named after Christmas-themed movies. Naturally, the titles conjured up the ‘80’s classics A Christmas Story and Gremlins.However, one group member (who shall rename nameless) hadn’t seen the latter movie, so the drink (made from Agalaves tequila, LeJay, lime juice and ginger beer) was enjoyed instead.

After our group committed to sharing entrées, we were drawn toward two vegetarian bowls and decided to take advantage of four taco offerings ($3 each) that coincided with “Taco Tuesday.” Although the menu allows customers to choose among four salsa options, we left that pairing up to the kitchen’s expertise.

Each of the proteins was neatly presented on a flour tortilla with various preparations: The tofu taco was finished with an herbaceous chimichurri sauce; the diced tomatoes and onions sprinkled atop the shrimp tempura taco helped us identify the Pico de Gallo; the delicately seasoned grilled cod taco was topped with a red traditional Mexican salsa known as salsa rojo, and the pulled pork, sweetened by a tasty sauce made from brown sugar and seasonings, was covered with a crunchy slaw of apple and kohlrabi. The trickiness of dividing up the tacos among the four of us quickly became apparent, but we carefully made it work.

What was ample for sharing was the $10 Bing bread (Chinese flat bread). Chef Asa Mott says it’s typical to see the Chinese street food cut in half and stuffed with braised pork or lamb. However, our preparation was “topped pizza style just for fun” and cut into triangles. The thick house-made bread (the dough is brushed with sesame oil and sprinkled with scallions before being rolled out several times and cooked on a plancha) was layered with a butternut squash purée and topped with crispy duck confit, quail eggs, tangy pecorino cheese and brightened by pickled red onions and cilantro.

Chef Asa jokes that even though ButaPub's sign has a giant pig on it, it was important for him to offer delicious vegetarian and vegan dishes, and our selection of the Panang Curry ($12) was an option brought back by popular demand this season. The hearty bowl consisted of winter squash, potatoes, cabbage, chickpeas, peanuts, coconut milk and rice, with dried red chilies that brought a welcome heat.

A simple preparation, the Cauliflower Fried Rice ($12) grabbed our attention and unexpectedly proved to be the group’s favorite entrée. Beneath a savory poached egg lay a half dozen soy pickled garlic gloves (bursts of which I considered delectable jewels) and small cauliflower pieces mixed with gluten-free soy sauce and fried rice. Sesame tahini imparted a toasted nuttiness and crunchy Parmesan crisps added the savory umami taste.

On the opposite spectrum of the vegetarian dishes is ButaPub’s famous pig head plate. Since it wasn’t printed on the current menu, I had to inquire about its availability. Chef Asa confirms diners can still place an order by calling 24 hours in advance. In addition, stay tuned to a new large format menu that will offer various cuts of meat for unique communal dining.
Innovative spins on classic desserts

Our third and final course put us at The Cub Room (739 S. Clinton Ave.), referred to as the Edge of the Wedge. A departure from our previous locations, the sizable restaurant evokes an industrial chic design with high ceilings giving way to exposed pipes, brick walls, wood pillars and dark tables. Lowlighting and votive candles across each table added sophisticated warmth. As we were led to an oversized half circle leather booth, we admired a beautiful outstretched peacock mural painted directly around and well above the table by local artist Amie Freling.

The Cub Room’s innovative bar program naturally lends itself to incorporating components into both confections, as well as enticing after-dinner drink options. With just four $8 house-made desserts (plus a special), the spirit of our food crawl made the decision to order one of each inevitable. However, our beverages were kept simple with a round of aromatic coffees and calming herbal teas ($3 each).

The moment our server set down the Cub Room S’mores (currently ranked the most popular), I found myself smiling at its captivating and substantial appearance. A graham cracker brownie was perched at the base, followed by a chocolate semifreddo (similar to a frozen mousse) and topped with a smoked marshmallow that blanketed the layers below. The mix of textures, flavors and temperatures deliciously portrayed Chef Greg Johnson’s intention of taking a classic comfort food and elevating it to a sexy status.

The Cub Room is known for its doughnut preparations, and we found the Bourbon Glazed “Manhattan” Donuts to be a treat that didn’t disappoint. Six doughnut holes showcased a marriage of fruit and alcohol in the distinctive jam filling, made from house-made rose vermouth and strawberries.

A twist on a typical cheesecake, the Goat’s Milk Cheesecake was also one of our preferred dishes of the night, due to its unique creamy and unexpected tart notes. It came topped with pumpkin mousse and a delightful scoop of snickerdoodle ice cream on the side.

While this food crawl represented just a small slice of a bigger wedge, it was refreshing to experience a variety of establishments purely passionate about food and drink. Lora pointed out that it was a fun way to approach an area of our home city like a tourist with curiosity, and Melody added how the thread of sharing was woven throughout the evening — from literally sharing dishes to memories and stories connected to food. Indeed, the discovery of new flavor combinations reminded us just how magical the culinary art form can be.
Adena Miller is a Rochester freelance writer.

articleBody.value: Last call: Backed by a red-hot band, Jenn Cristy and Troy Thomas Jr. re-create the best of Motown and R&B music (think Aretha Franklin, Janis Joplin, Stevie Wonder, and The Supremes) during Heart and Soul, being staged through Sunday, Jan. 22, at Downstairs Cabaret at Winton Place Plaza in Brighton. Tickets are $26. For more, including show times, go to downstairscabaret.com or call (585) 325-4370.

A screening of Stanley Kubrick’s 2001: A Space Odyssey starts at 2 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 22, at the Dryden Theatre at George Eastman Museum, 900 East Ave. Admission is $8; $4 for students with ID. Go to eastman.org or call (585) 271-4090.

Works by Mozart and Beethoven will be performed by Rebecca Penneys (piano), Mikhail Kopelman (violin) and Stefan Reuss (cello) at 2 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 22, at the Rochester Academy of Medicine, 1441 East Ave. Tickets are $35 for adults ($30 in advance); $5 for students. Go to raom.org/event-2283905.

Michael Butterman conducts Music of Mozart at 2 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 22, at Hochstein Performance Hall, 50 N. Plymouth Ave. Admission to the concert, featuring Juliana Athayde on violin and Melissa Matson on viola, is $27. Go to rpo.org or call (585) 454-2100.

Emancipation Denied: The Story of Black Wall Street is being staged by the North Star Players Monday through Saturday, Jan. 23 to 28, at MuCCC, 142 Atlantic Ave. Set in the early 1900s, the play (written by Rochester’s Deborah Solomon) tells of the hopes, struggles and successes of an African-American community in Tulsa, Oklahoma, dubbed “Black Wall Street” by Booker T. Washington because of its economic opportunities. Tickets are $7 to $15. To buy them, and for show times, go to muccc.org.

The Kilbourn Concert Series presents Boston Brass — Jeff Connor (trumpet), Jose Sibaja (trumpet), Chris Castellanos (horn), Domingo Pagliuca (trombone) and Sam Pilafian (tuba) — at 8 p.m. Tuesday, Jan. 24, at Kilbourn Hall, 26 Gibbs St. The first half of the show the band will present its favorite music (drawn from orchestra, opera, ballet, Broadway, jazz and movies); the second half the audience gets to choose via ballots. Tickets are $20 to $30. Go to eastmantheatre.org or call (585) 274-3000.

Rochester-based publisher BOA Editions is hosting a cross-genre reading from 6 to 9 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 26, at craft cocktail bar Nox, 302 N. Goodman St. Held in collaboration with Writers & Books, the event will feature BOA short fiction prize-winning author Douglas Watson, poet Michelle Y. Burke and fiction writer Rachel Hall. Admission is free. Go to BOA’s Facebook page.

Closing soon: A Matter of Memory closes Sunday, Jan. 29, at George Eastman Museum, 900 East Ave. The exhibit reflects on the potential consequences of photography’s “ongoing reorganization” from film and paper prints to digital files. Admission to the show is included in museum admission ($14; $12 for people 62 and older; $5 for students with ID; free for children 12 and younger). Go to eastman.org or call (585) 271-3361.

A Magical Journey Thru Stages presents Footloose, the Musical — based on the immensely popular 1984 movie about a small town where rock and roll and dancing are forbidden — from Friday, Jan. 27, through Sunday, Feb. 5, at the STAGES Theater, on the third floor of the Auditorium Center, 875 E. Main St. Tickets are $13 ($10 in advance). Go to mjtstages.com or call (585) 935-7173.

oembed.description: A film legend and a songwriting genius come to life in two cabaret shows this weekend
oembed.title: Marissa Mulder brings Marilyn Monroe, Tom Waits to Geva
oembed.html:
ROCHESTER DEMOCRAT AND CHRONICLE

Marissa Mulder brings Marilyn Monroe, Tom Waits to Geva

assets.author: Getty Images/iStockphoto, iStockphoto
assets.title: Vintage cello
assets.cutline: You have two opportunities to listen to live performances of music by Mozart on Sunday, Jan. 22.
assets.caption: You have two opportunities to listen to live performances of music by Mozart on Sunday, Jan. 22.

articleBody.value: 1 Disney on Ice: Passport to Adventure — in which Mickey and Minnie Mouse visit the worlds of The Lion King, The Little Mermaid, Peter Pan and Frozen — continues at Blue Cross Arena at the Community War Memorial through Sunday, Jan. 22. Tickets range from $15 to $80. To buy them, and for show times, go to ticketmaster.com or call (800) 745-3000.

2 Marissa Mulder will take the Fielding Stage at Geva Theatre Center for two cabaret shows. At 7:30 p.m. Friday, Jan. 20, Marilyn in Fragments — drawn from letters, poetry and songs by everyone from Cole Porter to Nine Inch Nails — will lead audience members on a journey with American icon Marilyn Monroe. Tom … In His Words, being staged at 8 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 21, brings to life the beat poetry and jazz-influenced music of Tom Waits. Tickets are $30 ($25 in advance); $40 VIP. Go to gevatheatre.org or call (585) 232-4382.

3 The Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, led by guest conductor George Daugherty, presents Bugs Bunny at the Symphony at 8 p.m. Friday and Saturday, Jan. 20 and 21, in Kodak Hall at the Eastman Theatre. Classic Looney Tunes favorites including The Rabbit of Seville and What’s Opera, Doc? will be projected on a big screen while the orchestra plays the original scores live. Tickets are $23 to $104. Go to rpo.org or call (585) 454-2100.

4 Nashville-based Americana duo Wisewater — Webster native Kate Lee and Forrest O’Connor, son of noted country fiddler Mark O’Connor — performs at 8 p.m. Friday, Jan. 20, at Nazareth College Arts Center’s Callahan Theatre. Tickets to the acoustic show are $25 to $35. Go to www2.naz.edu/events or call (585) 389-2170.

5 Nox Cocktail Lounge at Village Gate is hosting Doctor Who Night with Flower City Comic Con from 7 to 10 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 21. The evening will feature trivia, prizes, giveaways and Doctor Who-themed drinks. Go to Flower City Comic Con's Facebook page.

6 National touring exhibit Hands-On Harley-Davidson opens at The Strong National Museum of Play at 11 a.m. Saturday, Jan. 21. Visitors can explore a pretend engineering lab and motorcycle dealership and use science, technology, engineering and math concepts to design a bike, build a prototype and take a test drive. Admission is included with museum admission ($14.50 for ages 2 and older; free for children younger than 2). Museum hours are 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday through Thursday; 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Friday and Saturday; noon to 5 p.m. Sunday. At 7 p.m. Friday, Jan. 20, author Jean Davidson, granddaughter of Harley-Davidson co-founder Walter Davidson, will give a talk titled Growing Up Harley-Davidson at The Strong, which will be followed by a reception with light hors d’oeuvres. Admission to that event is $15; $20 includes general museum admission. Go to museumofplay.org or call (585) 263-2700.

7 Lovin’ Cup near RIT in Henrietta presents Homegrown — with food and beer samplings from local restaurants and breweries, and music by Danielle Ponder and the Tomorrow People, Honey Smugglers, the Moho Collective and other acts — from noon until 1 a.m. Saturday, Jan. 21. (The food and beer samplings will be available from noon to 9 p.m.; the music goes until 1 a.m.) Tickets are $30. Go to lovincup.com or call (585) 292-9940.

8 Nuts and Bolts Comedy Improv has an 8 p.m. show Saturday, Jan. 21, at Spotlight Theatre Arts on Railroad Street in Fairport. Tickets are $10. Go to Nuts and Bolts’ Facebook page or call (585) 683-1654.

9 Scratch Bakeshop on Park Avenue is hosting a 2-year Anniversary Party from noon to 5 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 22. The celebration will include T-shirt-design and pie-eating contests, raffles and free vegan doughnut holes. The shop will be joined by Ugly Duck Coffee and photo booth Hype Booth, and beer from Lost Borough Brew Co. and cider from Red Jack Orchards will be available. Go to Scratch Bakeshop’s Facebook page.

10 Alternative blues-rock outfit G Love and Special Sauce has a 6:30 p.m. show Sunday, Jan. 22 at Anthology. Tickets are $25 to $29. A ticket to G Love’s Pre-show Pop Off ($99) includes admission to the show, plus a pre-show performance and Q&A with G Love, a photo opportunity and an autographed limited-edition poster. Go to www.anthologylive.com or call (585) 423-1931.

articleBody.value: At a national education conference in 1996, Lisa Murphy wiggled her way into a sold-out session on new ways to use sensory tables — tables filled with sand, water and other materials that help young children learn about the world.

She waited patiently with about 700 others until a spokeswoman for the event announced from the stage that the presenter never showed up. Audience members started gathering their things in hopes of making it to another session.
Murphy turned to the woman next to her.
“I think I could do this.”
“Do what?” the woman asked.
“I could get up there and share ideas with everybody.”
The woman’s response: “I dare you.”

Murphy, at the time a family child care provider, took the stage, grabbed the microphone “and barked out every activity I knew how to do,” she recalls. “Everyone stayed. At the end they stood up and clapped and said they wanted to buy my book. I didn’t even have a handout.”

She did offer up her address, and for months afterward received letters of gratitude addressed to “The Ooey Gooey Lady.” Murphy assumed those words were part of the no-show presenter’s session description.
“My takeaway was that if people got this excited over something I made up, what if I actually started doing some actual work?”

Murphy, 47, is founder, president and CEO of Ooey Gooey, a company in Rochester that brings energetic, meaningful, research-based seminars and workshops to parents and early childhood educators and administrators around the globe. (The original name of her company was The Learning Through Adventure Company, but she couldn’t shed her “Ooey Gooey Lady” moniker and eventually stopped trying to brand herself differently.)

She spends between 250 and 300 days a year on the road, taking time off in July and December to “turn inward and reflect” on whether new research reinforces or changes her approach to creating successful child-centered environments for children from birth through age 8. Last year took her across the U.S. and to Canada and Tokyo. She already is scheduled to attend conferences this year in Lithuania and Finland.

“It’s always good to check in with the international scene to see what everyone is struggling with,” she says, “and also to see what’s working in other countries that we are so unwilling to implement.”
The author of four books, the most recent being Lisa Murphy on Play: The Foundation of Children’s Learning, Murphy is penning the fifth this year for Redleaf Press, to be published in 2018.

Her following is growing. The podcast she has recorded for four years with Jeff Johnson, founder of an Iowa-based company that promotes playful learning, just reached 250,000 downloads — 150,000 of them in 2016 alone. The podcast is called “Child Care Bar and Grill,” paying homage to worthwhile conversations that often take place between conferences, in school hallways and “over a beer at the end of the day,” explains Murphy. “This is about strong content in an informal atmosphere.”

Notes Johnson of Explorations Early Learning: “Lisa is outgoing and vivacious. I was amazed the first time I knew that she had fallen asleep; I didn’t think that happened because she’s always on the go. And her energy doesn’t change. A lot of people turn it on just to do a gig, but with her it’s a constant thing, and that grows her business.”

Murphy tries to help other professionals grow by getting them to seriously think about why they do what they do. The joke, she says, is that early childhood educators get into the field for the apple mugs and scented candles.

“But it goes deeper than that,” she adds. “The reality is we’re not going to love every kid who comes into the classroom; that’s some superficial, fragile belief. Being willing to stick with it and find that thread of connection where it’s not as obvious as with other kids in the classroom — that’s what makes you good. It’s about compassion and commitment and stretching yourself to meet those children wherever they are, which is exhausting work.”
For her own professional development, Murphy attends conferences, reads copious numbers of books, and constantly writes up reports for social media on the things she learns from both.
“You don’t ever wake up and think you’re done,” she says. “The minute you think you’ve got it all handled is the day you need to quit.”
Robin L. Flanigan is a freelance writer in the Rochester area.

content.headline: Rochester's Ooey-Gooey Lady gains podcast following
