articleBody.value: What happens when you elevate bar food, offer 72 beers, create craft cocktails using local spirits and mount 25 flat-screen televisions to the wall? A restaurant bar unlike any other west of Rochester.

Those TVs — the majority of which are 4K ultra high definition — are the first things you notice when you arrive at Clutch Kitchen and Sports Bar in Greece. You’re not missing a moment of the game when surrounded by all of the bright pixels shining from the walls.

Open since September, the large bar was adopted from the previous establishment, Paddington’s Pub and Plate, and is one of the only fixtures to remain. New booths and tables with intimate lighting create a cozy side to the dining room.

A serious beverage program includes 22 draft beers with eight on rotation as well as menus devoted entirely to mules and specialty cocktails. Beer by the bottle and wine are also available. Coming soon is a collaboration with a local distillery, Black Button, and a cocktail menu exclusively showcasing their spirits.

On the Tuesday night of our visit, they were short-staffed, with only one server responsible for the moderate-sized dining crowd. She was as attentive as possible, but walked by our table multiple times when our order could have been taken and later when we could have been checked on.

First to arrive were the hot buttered pretzel sticks ($7). Glistening with butter and coarse salt, they made perfect dippers into the two delicious accompanying sauces — a cheese sauce enhanced by Rohrbach’s Scotch Ale and a whole grain mustard-mayo mixture. Soft and steamy, these are the perfect pairing to a pint of your choice.
One shrimp and one pork taco rested in a metal stand as an evening special at $3 each. Choices of chicken or beef fillings were also available.

The pulled pork is typically used on the nachos as well as a sandwich. Here it was folded into a soft white tortilla shell along with pico de gallo, shredded cheddar cheese and lettuce. House smoked, it took on a sweet barbecue element, but it was on the cold side. Chilled sour cream on the side didn’t help to warm things up either.
However, two beer-battered shrimps were nicely cooked and welcomingly warm alongside the same fillings as the pork version.

It wouldn’t be a proper visit without trying the chicken wings. We opted for the signature Clutch sauce on the side, whereas typically the wings are fried, sauced, grilled, then sauced again. Ours (10 for $10) still took on a unique smoky flavor from the extra step of grilling, and the sauce intrigued. At first taste it was a blend of barbecue and Buffalo. This housemade creation takes on 18 ingredients and imparts sweet, smoky and spicy tastes.

In case you’re more in the mood for a garden-fresh dish, the iceberg wedge salad ($9) is a good choice. Once you’ve worked the serrated knife through the quarter head of lettuce, a lovely basil buttermilk dressing liberally coats the greens. Slivered crunchy carrots and halved sweet red and yellow cherry tomatoes mingled well with the savory bacon and pungent bleu cheese crumbled overtop.

The Buffalo chicken cutlet sandwich ($9.50) was served on a custom-made roll supplied by Fairport-based Amazing Grains Bread Co. A juicy Panko-crusted chicken breast was smothered in a classic Buffalo sauce. Sliced tomato, lettuce and bleu cheese crumbles rounded flavors out. Taste-wise it was highly satisfying, but the sandwich’s assembly, with the bun sitting in a pool of extra sauce and the awkward placement of the lettuce and tomato, kept it from staying put.
Extra effort is displayed in the crisp truffle-scented potato chips that are made daily and served in a miniature deep-fryer basket on the side of the sandwiches.

We overheard a neighboring table order a salted caramel cookie skillet ($9) for dessert and promptly put in our request for one. The made-per-order dish is worth the 15-minute wait. A dough composed of white chocolate, toffee and crushed pretzels is pressed into a small cast iron pan and baked until just done. A mound of vanilla ice cream effortlessly melts into the warm cookie, while a heavy drizzle of caramel sauce takes this dessert to another sweet level. It’s great for sharing.

Clutch wants to raise the bar when it comes to combining good drinks, comfort food and sports entertainment. With Super Bowl around the corner and more enhancements on the way, such as a boozy weekend brunch and custom-made furnishings, co-owner Eric Clark’s drive and passion to put out game-winning recipes and capture the right audience is refreshing.
Amanda Antinore, a freelance writer, reviews restaurants after a one-time visit.
Clutch Kitchen and Sports Bar
Location: 3208 Latta Road, Greece; (585) 270-4350.
Website:clutchkitchen.com.
Hours: 4 p.m. to midnight Monday through Thursday; noon to 2 a.m. Friday and Saturday: noon to midnight Sunday.
Appetizers: $7 to $15.
Entrées: $9 to $39.
Diet: Can accommodate special requests and dietary restrictions; Vegetarian and gluten-free friendly.
Handicapped-accessible: Yes. Fully wheelchair friendly.
Reservations: Yes.
Kid-friendly: Yes; High chairs and booster seats available.
Attire: Casual.
Credit cards accepted: Yes.
Parking: Free in parking lot in front of restaurant.
Casual eateries with better-than-average pub food, sports entertainment

A series of restaurant reviews is focusing on casual establishments for enjoying better-than-average pub fare while viewing sporting events. These are the places that go beyond throwing wings in the fryer; they offer imaginative dishes and make at least some of their menu items from scratch.

articleBody.value: The joint: 1205 Spencerport Road, Gates; (585) 413-0757.
The meal: Cheeseburger and fries
The check: $7.34 (!)
Burger Hunt series:
Cheap Eats continues its occasional series on notable local options for a burger and fries. We’re trying burgers with “everything” that comes at the basic price, and a side of fries if available.
The story:

Rochester’s storied food history involves a bunch of burger joints named for dudes: Don and Bob’s, Vic and Irv’s, Jim and Ralph’s, Don’s Original. And history overlaps here: Nello Nucelli, a member of the Canadian Boxing Hall of Fame and father to twins Jim and Ralph Nucelli (of Jim and Ralph’s), started out as a manager at Don and Bob’s. Since Jim and Ralph’s closed, Jim Nucelli’s children, Kyle, Lindsay and Jimmy, have carried on the family tradition at Jim’s Ground.
This was the cheapest cheeseburger and fries we’ve had during our occasional Burger Hunt; $7.34 for a filling meal is stunning in 2017. But it wouldn’t matter if the quality were iffy.

It is not. The boast on the sign is, “The Best Ground Around,” and it was, in fact, the best Rochester-style ground round I’ve had. At our burger joints, the “ground round” is a pressed burger either grilled or fried (grilled at Jim’s). Pressing can leave a burger dense and tough, but burgerologist Stan Merrell and I were bowled over by the tender, juicy burger inside. It was not just a grill-flavored excuse for toppings, but a delicious burger on its own. Kudos to the Nucelli kids.

“Everything” on my cheeseburger meant mustard (a Rochester must-have), American cheese, chopped onion, pickle relish (sweet) and hot sauce (Rochester-style meat sauce). As I’ve explained before, the classic Rochester burger has sharp toppings, not sweet. That can go a bit far for my taste, and I often put a good bit of ketchup on, or hope for sweet pickles. But this set of flavors complements that delicious burger very nicely (with just the bit of sweet from the relish). The hot sauce could be spicier, but I quibble. Lettuce, tomato, mayo, hot peppers and ketchup are also free options.

“Hard roll” in our burger joint parlance means a roll that isn’t very hard but has some crispness to its crust. The hard roll at Jim’s (from Di Paolo’s; sub rolls are from Martusciello’s) is large, with just a bit of cracker to the crust, airy but not Wonder bread soft. It holds up but doesn’t intrude.

The Burgerologist is picky about fries. He’s fine with a product (as opposed to fresh-cut), but not OK with a coating. He pronounced these “very good,” a crinkle-cut product with enough of both crispy exterior and pillowy interior. He said they could have used another 15 seconds in the fryer but was not complaining. And the “small” order at $2.05 was more than I needed.
The options:

So many sandwiches, none hitting $9. A bacon cheeseburger, for example, is just $5.25. There are red hots and white hots ($2.85), beef on 'weck wick (that’s roast beef on a kimmelweck roll, if you ain’t from these parts, for $7.50), BLT ($5.25), steak bomber (small $7.50, large $8.95) and fried bologna ($5.99/$7.99) among many others. Chicken? Fried or grilled, $7.25.

Showing that Jim’s is owned by a younger generation, there are wraps and salads. Wraps come with chicken, tuna, ham or more for $7.25. Salads bring a choice of iceberg or romaine lettuce with several dressings. Side salads are $2.75, while meal-sized range from $7.25 to $8.95.

The menu of sides is extensive. In addition to the standard (crinkle-cut) fries, there are fries of the cheese, sweet potato, curly and home-fried varieties. If you want to mix your healthy with your unhealthy, try breaded cauliflower or mushrooms. And there’s mac salad, and slaw, and chili, and soup and on and on. Fish fry on Friday? Check.
And the Burgerologist liked the milkshake (small $2.50, large $5). It’s the real deal, made from ice cream, but no malt.

Another win for Jim’s is screaming deals for the kids: $3.80 for a main dish (burger, hot, nuggets, etc), fries and soft drink. Let’s say you’re a family of four with two kids under 12. You all get cheeseburgers and fries, you split one of the huge milkshakes. That’s $28.29 including tax. Can’t beat that with a stick.

Unless you get a whole lot of wings, there is nothing on the Jim’s Ground menu that costs 10 ten bucks. Considering the overall high quality, Jim’s provides one of the best values I’ve seen in Rochester.
What about the plate?

Two varieties. The Slop Plate includes two hots or one cheeseburger over mac salad and home fries (with your toppings choice) for $7.50. The All American Plate is two hots or two mini burgers with baked beans over mac salad and home fries ($7.95). Like a different combo? Kyle Nucelli says just ask. I didn’t try one, but next time for sure.
Freelance writer Adam Wilcox is as Rochester as meat hot sauce.

articleBody.value: As an alternative to going out, critic Jack Garner recommends:

Bad Day At Black Rock: This is a strange and enthralling mystery-drama, combining aspects of the Western and film noir, but in the blazing sun of the post-war American West of the 1950s. A one-armed stranger (Spencer Tracy) gets off the train, in search of a man. His search uncovered anti-Japanese-American sentiment in the town, which leads to threats and violence, and a powerful showdown. The film's cast is fabulous, and includes Robert Ryan, Anne Francis, Walter Brennan, Lee Marvin and Ernest Borgnine.
Director:  John Sturges.
Cast: Tracy, Ryan, Borgnine, John Ericson Dean Jagger.
Jack’s rating: 10.

New on DVD this week: Zero Days, The Girl on the Train, Bad Day at Black Rock (Blu-ray), Keeping Up with the Joneses, Come and Find Me, Rizzoli & Isles: Final Season, Surf's 2: Wave Mania, The Hollow Point, The Whole Truth, When Elephants Were Young.

Next week:The Man Who Fell to Earth (Blu-ray), Wait Until Dark (Blu-ray), Sherlock: Season 4, USS Indianapolis, The Light Between Oceans, I'm Not Ashamed, Poltergeist III, Boy Did I Get a Wrong Number.

articleBody.value: The joint: Sabra Grill, 1855 Monroe Ave., Brighton; (585) 244-2211
The meal: Hamsa plate (salad sampler)
The check: $10.80
The story:
Middle Eastern joints are popping up all over the area, and that is a grand thing.

You can get shawarma from Turks, Afghans and Iraqis; tabbouleh from the Lebanese; and koshmari from Egyptians. Until a couple years ago, though, the Israelis haven’t been represented in the Roc, which is odd considering our large Jewish population. But along came Sabra Grill to fill the void.

I’m a huge fan of Eastern Mediterranean mezze (basically appetizers), and the lush, colorful assortment at Sabra is thrilling. Most local Middle Eastern restaurants have three to five, two of which are always hummus and baba ghanoush. Sabra had 13 on the day we went!
You can get one as a side with a plate, but how would you decide?

Fortunately, the hamsa plate is there for mezze addicts. It comes with your choice of five of the salads, piled high with a fresh pita on top. Our server assured me he was not simply being nice, and that this was The Way. It was more than I could eat.

I left myself to the server’s mercy on selection. He gave me tabouli with large-grained bulgur that had a lot of tooth. It was lemony, which is good, but short on parsley for my taste. (This is religion … my Lebanese college roommate treated tabouli as a parsley salad with a bit of bulgur.) Moroccan beet salad was not for the faint of heart, with cubed beets in a strong vinaigrette.

Israeli salad, which goes on many of Sabra’s sandwiches, is chopped cucumbers, tomatoes and onions with a bit of green. It’s either undressed or very lightly dressed with lemon, and I liked that the vegetables were allowed their own flavors in this way. Broccoli salad is a slaw of broccoli, red cabbage, red pepper and carrot in a light mayo dressing. It’s vibrant with green, red, orange and purple.

Perhaps the most interesting of the salads was a roasted squash salad. The roasted vegetables had concentrated flavor, and were dressed with a syrupy coating. It was sweet, salty (olive), a little smoky and intense.

The pitas at Sabra, while small in circumference, are much more substantial than what you often see. They’re more like a good, airy bread in circular form, good for absorbing sauces and dressings. I’m looking forward to trying them with completely different assortments of salads on my next couple of visits.
The options:

The toppings and salads bar, as mentioned, goes on and on. There were at least four forms of eggplant on our trip. Sabra’s babganoush (every restaurant has its own spelling) is smoky, relatively smooth-textured and a tad bitter. The “salad” that was just roasted eggplant looked fabulous and will be on my plate next time.

Other salads/toppings include hummus and tahini (of course), amba (pickled mango), matbucha (Moroccan hot pepper and tomato), pickled cabbage, Israeli pickles, Moroccan carrot salad, cucumbers in a dill vinaigrette, and daily specials. Sabra makes almost all of these. Come on; that’s exciting, right?

Of course there are shawarma, kebabs and falafel, served in a pita or as a plate. Sabra’s shawarma is made with turkey, which is unusual ($11 for a sandwich, $13 as a plate). Plates, by the by, include Israeli salad, hummus, tahini and a pickle.

My friend Josh says the falafel sandwich ($8) is about his favorite lunch in town. The falafel themselves are kind of green, which we’re guessing is because of parsley. Josh gets it with “the works,” which is Israeli salad, pickles and who-knows-what, but he likes his tahini on the side to keep the pita from getting soggy.
Kebabs are made of spiced ground beef ($11/$13), and chicken comes in skewered (“pargiot”) or grilled breast form ($11/$13).

I loved the latke, which was very crisp on the outside, but with a soft, mashed potato interior. Josh is a latke epicure, having been raised on his mom’s and regularly making his own. To his taste, these might have been good, but they aren’t latkes. Expectations rule.

Another win for Sabra is a large assortment of non-alcoholic beverages. In addition to Coke products, there are Snapple and Honest teas, plus New York City favorites from Dr. Brown’s (including Cel-Ray, certainly an acquired taste), and several varieties of an Israeli juice brand; I loved the mango.

Don’t forget to ask … for a kubeh. Called “kibbeh” in other places, this is fried dough stuffed with ground, spiced meat. Kissing cousin to Hispanic papas rellenas and alcapurria, Sabra’s version has a thick and crispy exterior with a small amount of extremely flavorful meat inside.
Freelance writer Adam Wilcox’s taste in grilled eggplant knows no borders.
